citation.article-title: Transfer of Propionibacterium innocuum Pitcher and Collins 1991 to Propioniferax gen. nov. as Propioniferax innocua comb. nov.

p.s: Propioniferax (Pro.pi.on.i.fe'rax. M.L. n. acidum propionicum, propionic acid; L. adj. ferax, fertile; M.L. n. propioniferax, propionic acid-producing)
Cells are gram-positive, non-acid fast, nonmotile, nonsporing, pleomorphic rods appearing in clusters and V forms.
Colonies are white, shining, and convex to domed.
The optimum growth temperature is approximately 37°C.
Facultatively anaerobic but luxuriant growth occurs aerobically (approximately 0.5 to 3 mm of growth on nutrient or horse blood agar at 37°C for 2 days).
Cell wall contains LL-A2pm, arabinose, and mannose but not galactose.
Glycine forms the interpeptide bridge of peptidoglycan.
Mycolic acids are not present, Major fatty acids are anteiso-15:O and iso-15:O.
The major respiratory quinone is MK-9(H4).
The G+C content of the DNA is 59 to 63 mol%.
The genus Propioniferax is a member of the Propionibacterium-Luteococcus-Aeromicrobium- Nocardioides line of descent within the radiation of the ordertictinomycetales.
Its phylogenetic neighbor is L. japonicus (Fig. 1).
The type species is Propioniferax innocua.
